intro.en:
Accessibility Auditor

After completing the learning path, you will have a basic understanding of the technologies that the Web is built on, a basic understanding of accessibility as it pertains to the Web, mobile, documents, and eventually desktop; and how to build and evaluate rich internet applications. No course can be exhaustive. Most knowledge will be gained through experience. This learning path will lay the foundation allowing you to build upon it as you practice web development and accessibility auditing.

Most training courses in this learning path will either be free, or readily paid for. (Courses are free unless a cost is listed.) Most are self-paced and start as soon as you want so you can start learning without delay.

Note: the courses provided by the Government of Canada are available in both Official Languages. The rest, however, are mostly English only.

Target Audience:

  • Web Accessibility Auditors
  • Those interested in web development with an eye towards accessibility

objective.en: You will learn the fundamental building blocks of a website: HTML, CSS, JavaScript, and build a simple website hosted on GitHub pages.

note.en:
What does this have to do with accessibility?

It's said that the best way to identify a counterfeit dollar bill is to know what a real dollar bill looks like. Likewise, the best way to spot bad HTML is to know proper HTML. HTML was designed from the beginning to be accessible to users of assistive technologies.

HTML is a semantic language, meaning that its elements have meaning. Certain HTML elements expose themselves to assistive technologies in special ways. For example, an <h1> may look big and bold, but it means that it's a top-level heading. The difference between regular text styled to look big and bold is completely different to a screen reader user. It is important to understand the meaning behind the different HTML elements and attributes.

What does Git Have To With Accessibility

Nowadays, in a technical field such as web development, knowing Git is a bit like knowing about MS Excel Pivot Tables in data analysis. You can probably get by for a while without knowing it. But sooner or later you're going to need to learn it. You don't need to become an expert. But when time comes to use it, you don't want to be starting from scratch.

You'll start by building a small website. GitHub allows websites to be hosted on their GH Pages. So before doing that, we'll start with learning basic Git.

activity.en:
1. Create an account on {{urls[0]}}
  2. Create a public repo
  3. Create a README.md file (this can be part of the repo-creation process)
  4. Edit the README.md file:
    1. Install Git on your local computer
    2. Clone your repo locally
    3. Create a branch
    4. Edit README.md in your text editor of choice, and add content. Save file.
  5. Commit changes locally
  6. Push your branch to GitHub
  7. Merge your changes to the main branch on {{urls[0]}}
  8. Delete your old branch on {{urls[0]}} and locally.
  9. Create a new branch called gh-pages
  10. Set up Pages on that repo. In this step you can specify what branch will be in production. The default is gh-pages at path / (root). For the purposes of this, we'll assume you go with that.
  11. Merge (ie: Pull Request) the main branch to gh-pages.
  12. Visit https://[yourUserName].github.io/reponame/README.md to see your README.me in production. (If your browser doesn't read markdown files natively, you may be offered to download the file instead or open in another program.)
  13. Send these URLs (your Repo and the README URL on GitHub Pages) to the Team Lead or Technical Advisor overseeing your training.

goal.en: Demonstrate your knowledge of HTML by starting a website.

activity.en:
1. Using the GitHub repo you created earlier, create a website. (Just HTML for now. We'll add CSS and JavaScript later.) The purpose of the site can be anything you want (your pets, your favourite sports team, a fictitious restaurant, etc. just nothing naughty, unethical, or illegal), and it should have at least the following:

    • Around 3 to 5 pages
    • One of the pages should have the filename index.html
    • A decorative image
    • A non-decorative image
    • At least one list
    • A table
    • Links
    • Header, site nav, footer, and main section
    • Headings
    • A form with input elements including a button of some kind ("Submit", "Go", etc.) (The form doesn't have to work, just have it there. Functionality will be added later.)
    • List 3 principles that are relevant to accessibility issues encountered in web applications.

    At this point there should be no CSS or JavaScript or Aria. We'll add those later.

    Publish using GH-Pages on the repo created earlier. Send the link to the Team Lead or Technical Advisor overseeing your training.

    We're looking for valid, and proper HTML use.

1. Modify the website created in the HTML portion (above) to have styling. The look and feel is up to you. But include CSS in the following ways:

activity.en:
1. Modify the website created in the HTML and CSS portions (above) to have added functionality. Part of the website should have some form elements. Now is the time to add functionality. Implement the following functionality:

    • There should be a button that when clicked takes a value in one of the <input>s and puts either that value, or the result of a calculation based on that value somewhere else on the webpage. This could be as simple as an input that asks for your name, then when the button is pressed, a message appears on the page that says "Hello [name entered here]". Or it could be a simple calculator, like asking for a number and when the button is clicked, the square of the number appears on the page.

    This doesn't have to be complex. Just enough to show that you understand how to listen for a "click" event, get the value of an input, and add content to the page.

    Also, this is for JavaScript. Not JQuery, Angular, React, Vue, etc. Plain, vanilla JavaScript.

    Send the link to the Team Lead or Technical Advisor overseeing your training.

objective.en: To learn the fundamental principles of accessibility, WCAG (Web Content Accessibility Guidelines) 2.1 at the AA level, and performing accessibility audits.

note.en:
Now that you have a foundation of web development, it's time to build on that. We now turn our attention to accessibility and WCAG.

The term "Accessible" could be defined as "usable by all". Whether or not something, say a website, is accessible is somewhat subjective. Having a standard makes it objective. WCAG 2.1 (Level AA) is the standard we use. As an example, how much contrast between adjacent colours is needed varies by user. WCAG gives a definitive answer: for text against background, it's 4.5 to 1.

It's important to understand basic accessibility principles like different disability groups and how they each interact with the Web. And it's important to know WCAG so you can interpret, apply, and reference it during an accessibility audit.

As for which specific courses to take, there is some choice. Ideally, you should take the T716 course offered by Canada School of the Public Service. But spots may not be readily available. Alternatively, the Accessibility for Web Development course offered by ESDC College is offered more frequently. But it's not as in-depth, and it can still be a few weeks before you can get a spot. And you want to start learning now.

Below are some options to get you started today.

purpose.en: Provide practice performing a set of audits and re-audits on a small website. Pretend that the Team Lead or Technical Advisor who is overseeing your training is your client. They have a website they need to get out to production. But it needs to adhere to the departmental standards on Accessibility first. You're going to help them with that. activity.en:
1. Perform an accessibility audit on {{urls[0]}} and send your findings to Team Lead or Technical Advisor overseeing your training.
  2. The Team Lead or Technical Advisor will check your audit for clear communication on issues, properly identified issues, missed issues, and false positives. They'll give you feedback, along with a new URL to audit. That new URL will be copy of the site in the previous step, with some or all of the accessibility issues fixed.
  3. Perform a re-audit on the site at the new URL, setting fixed issues as "Pass", adding any new issues if you find any. Send your report back to your Team Lead or Technical Advisor.
  4. Steps 2 and 3 will be repeated until you've performed a re-audit on a website with no accessibility issues. When you send your finished audit with no failures and a Conformance Email to your Team Lead or Technical Advisor, they will confirm that you have just audited a site with no failures, and this activity will be complete.

objective.en: To learn the fundamental principles of accessibility as it applies to Mobile devices and apps.

note.en: The most important part of learning mobile accessibility is learning to use a screen reader on a mobile device - without a keyboard. On desktops, keyboards are part of the screen reader experience. You need to learn shortcuts and hotkeys. You need to be able to use the computer without a mouse plus the screen reader shortcuts. But for mobile, you need to learn to use a screen reader using only your fingers. While mobile devices can have keyboards connected, finger-only usage would be considered the primary way to interact.

objective.en: To take your ability to audit to the next level. This includes understanding WAI-ARIA (Web Accessibility Initiative – Accessible Rich Internet Applications), and ATAG (Authoring Tools Accessibility Guidelines).

note.en:
WAI-ARIA

Now that you have a foundation of web development and accessibility, it's time to build on that. We now turn our attention to WAI-ARIA, or "ARIA" for short.

ARIA is used to enhance accessibility in web applications. You will need to be able to identify improper ARIA in web audits, and offer advice on how to fix errors.

Learning WAI-ARIA is a years-long pursuit, learning what roles require which parent and child roles, which stand on their own, what browser and screen reader combos support what aria, etc. But you will run into WAI-ARIA sooner rather than later.

Below are some options to get you started today.

activity.en:
In part 3 of Block B you added JavaScript that would add some text to the page when the user clicked a button. Now add appropriate ARIA to make the page accessible:

  • For the text that's added when the user clicks the button, ensure a screen reader would be notified of that text without moving the user's focus.
  • If any of the <input>s on the page have extra instructions or help text, or anything a screen reader will miss in Forms Mode, ensure that information will be exposed to screen readers using the proper ARIA. If none of the s have any help text or inline instruction, add some and ensure it's properly exposed to screen readers.
  • Optional: Implement one of the following on your page:
    1. Aria menu
    2. Tabbed Interface
  • Update any parts of the site that could be implemented with greater accessibility.

    • Send the link to the Team Lead or Technical Advisor overseeing your training.
